channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Letter From Europe: After Vote, a Rubicon Moment for E.U.?
item.description: Anti-European groups chose the European Parliament as their Trojan horse to assail the European Union from within.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: An Afghan migrant looked out the window of his makeshift shelter on Monday in Calais, northern France.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: ‘Naked Officials’ Feel Heat of China Anticorruption Drive
item.description: The government is hiring growing numbers of bureaucrats to join its civil service, while also targeting those “naked officials” who send their families abroad while enjoying the perks of the job back home.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Candidates gather for the national civil service examination at a university in Hefei, Anhui Province.

item.title: World Briefing: Turkish Court Says YouTube Ban Is Unconstitutional
item.description: Turkey’s highest court ruled Thursday that a government ban on the video-sharing site YouTube was unconstitutional and a violation of freedom of expression.
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: The Big Fix: A Price Tag on Carbon as a Climate Rescue Plan
item.description: From China to Norway, Kazakhstan to the Northeastern United States, governments are requiring industries to buy permits allowing them to emit set levels of greenhouse gases.
item.dc:creator: By JUSTIN GILLIS
item.media:credit: Sally Ryan for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Wisconsin farm, where cash incentives help cut greenhouse-causing methane emissions.

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq War Inquiry Gets Bits of Leaders’ Talks in Britain
item.description: The British government agreed on Thursday to give the “gist” of conversations between Prime Minister Tony Blair and President George W. Bush while they were in office to an inquiry panel looking into the Iraq war.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: World Briefing: Director of ‘Happy in Tehran’ Video Freed on Bail in Iran
item.description: Sassan Soleimani, the director of “Happy in Tehran,” a viral YouTube rendition of a Pharrell Williams music video, was released on bail on Thursday.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: World Briefing: Online Chats Between Sexes Denounced in Saudi Arabia
item.description: A senior Saudi Arabian cleric has issued an edict against online chatting between the sexes.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China’s Most-Hated Official Is No Surprise
item.description: Urban management officials, or chengguan, are ranked last in popularity, behind school and hospital officials, village cadres, the police and bosses of state-owned enterprises.
item.dc:creator: By KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: Chengguan officers, charged with enforcing urban order, explaining to a citizen why a motorcycle parked in the street violated city regulations.

item.title: U.S. Strategy to Fight Terrorism Increasingly Uses Proxies
item.description: Even before President Obama’s speech on a shift in antiterrorism strategy, the military began relying more on allied or indigenous troops to combat Al Qaeda and its affiliates.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: President Obama at West Point on Wednesday, outlining a shift in counterterrorism strategy.

item.title: Foreign Jihadis Fighting in Syria Pose Risk in West
item.description: As many as 3,000 Westerners are believed to have gone to Syria to fight, prompting more aggressive efforts by governments to take action against domestic threats.
item.dc:creator: By KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:description: Syrian activists and jihadist social media sites reported that the American went by the name Abu Huraira al-Amriki and carried out the suicide truck bombing in the northern province of Idlib.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: At Core of Church-State Clash, Unease Over Christianity’s Rising Influence in China
item.description: As Christianity continues its rapid rise in China, some believers feels discriminated against by public policies and say the government favors traditional Chinese religions.
item.dc:creator: By JONAH M. KESSEL

item.title: N.S.A. Releases Email That It Says Undercuts Snowden’s Whistle-Blower Claim
item.description: The message made no reference to government collection of data of the former contractor’s privacy concerns. Instead, he was seeking clarification of the laws governing the agency.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: The N.S.A. acted after NBC interviewed Edward J. Snowden.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Nobel Laureate’s Release from Prison May Hinge on His ‘Regret’
item.description: Liu Xiaobo, who was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2011 and is serving an 11-year prison term for subversion, is the world’s only jailed Nobel laureate. On June 8, under Chinese law, he become eligible for parole.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Pakistan Killing Has a New Twist
item.description: The husband of a woman stoned to death this week was arrested in 2009 for killing his first wife, but the case against Muhammad Iqbal was dropped.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: With Main Parties in Disarray, France’s Far Right Benefits
item.description: In her recent election campaign, Marine Le Pen portrayed mainstream politicians as corrupt. As if on cue, the main conservative party acknowledged using false invoices in 2012.
item.dc:creator: By SUZANNE DALEY and SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: Pro-Russia Troops Take Symbol of Ukraine Uprising
item.description: In a sign that commanders with Russian citizenship appear to be gaining control of the rebellion in Ukraine, the Vostok Battalion evicts a group of locals from the administration building in Donetsk.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH and SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: Smoke rose from the crash site of a Ukrainian Army helicopter on Thursday outside Slovyansk.

item.title: Donji-Ri Journal: An Island Marred by a Ferry Disaster and Sustained by Dogs
item.description: Before a deadly ferry sinking in April, the South Korean island of Jindo was known largely for one thing: its dogs, famous for their loyalty and homing instinct.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Jean Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fourth-generation descendant of the famous Baekgu, with Lee Ki-seo, son of Baekgu’s owner.

item.title: Boehner and Pelosi Resist Cries for Ouster of Veterans Affairs Chief
item.description: The House and Senate are confronting the broadening health scandal at the department in ways that will challenge both parties to rethink the future of the medical system for veterans.
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: Eric Shinseki, the Veterans Affairs secretary, testified before the Senate on May 15.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Price of a Sex-Slave Rescue Fantasy
item.description: An anti-trafficking icon’s stories led to policies that harmed women.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA GIRA GRANT

item.title: Church-State Clash in China Coalesces Around a Toppled Spire
item.description: In ordering a church in Wenzhou torn down, Chinese officials said it violated zoning regulations, but an internal document describes a strategy to reduce Christianity’s public profile.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON
item.media:credit: Sim Chi Yin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A state-sanctioned church in Wenzhou, run by the Three-Self Patriotic Movement. Churches across Zhejiang Province have been told to take down crosses.

item.title: International Observers Find Egypt’s Presidential Election Fell Short of Standards
item.description: Two teams of foreign observers said the presidential election was marred by irregularities and a repressive political environment.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Abbas Seeks a New Government That Would Seal Alliance With Hamas
item.description: The move could send Israeli-Palestinian relations into a tailspin and would disrupt any prospect of a resumption of American-brokered peace talks.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: French Will Host Putin at D-Day Rites
item.description: With 70th anniversary commemorations of D-Day as a backdrop, the meeting will constitute the French president’s most prominent diplomatic foray into the Ukrainian crisis since it began.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE and SUZANNE DALEY

item.title: North Korea Will Investigate Fate of Abducted Japanese
item.description: Japan, in return, said it would start lifting sanctions it had imposed on the North, which in 2002 admitted the abductions.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Rapes in India Fuel Charges of Conspiracy by a Caste
item.description: Two girls, cousins ages 15 and 14, were found dead, their bodies hanging from mango trees in Uttar Pradesh State.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS and HARI KUMAR
